nodes.label: NAMCS HC Data
nodes.detail: 9M+ annual FQHC visit records — the base for all probabilistic linkages to external datasets
nodes.who: Researchers, epidemiologists, public health analysts, and policy makers studying FQHC populations
nodes.what: 9M+ annual FQHC visit records with diagnoses, medications, demographics, and visit characteristics
nodes.when: 2021 onwards — full-year EHR submissions; public files released 18–24 months after the collection year
nodes.where: 95+ FQHCs across the U.S. Public files via NCHS; restricted files at FSRDC secure facilities
nodes.why: Fills a critical gap in FQHC-specific patient-centered outcomes research for underserved populations
nodes.which: Four access routes: dashboard, public file, restricted RDC file, and record linkage
nodes.how: Participating FQHCs submit HL7-formatted EHR encounter data; NCHS applies weighting and disclosure controls

nodes.label: HUD Housing
nodes.detail: HUD administrative records on housing assistance — public housing, Section 8 vouchers, rental assistance
nodes.who: HUD-assisted households — public housing tenants, Section 8 voucher holders, rental assistance recipients
nodes.what: Housing assistance participation records: program type, duration, household characteristics
nodes.when: Linked data reflects housing status at time of FQHC visit; available ~2–3 years after encounter collection
nodes.where: Restricted access only — all analysis within FSRDC secure computing environments
nodes.why: Adds housing stability and affordability context invisible in the clinical encounter record
nodes.which: Public housing, Housing Choice Voucher (Section 8), and project-based rental assistance programs
nodes.how: Probabilistic match on name, date of birth, SSN, and residential address by NCHS data linking specialists

nodes.label: Death Index
nodes.detail: National Death Index — mortality status, date and cause of death for all U.S. deaths since 1979
nodes.who: Complete national mortality registry — all deaths in the United States regardless of location
nodes.what: Mortality status, date of death, underlying cause (ICD-10-CM), and contributing causes of death
nodes.when: NDI records lag 2–3 years; enables long-term survival analysis from 2021 FQHC encounters onward
nodes.where: Matching performed by NCHS specialists in secure environments; linked files only at FSRDC
nodes.why: Transforms cross-sectional visit data into longitudinal cohorts with definitive mortality ascertainment
nodes.which: All-cause mortality, cause-specific mortality, and preventable death analyses
nodes.how: Probabilistic match using name, SSN, date of birth, sex, race, and state of residence — >90% match rate

nodes.label: Medicaid
nodes.detail: CMS Medicaid enrollment and claims files — insurance continuity and downstream service utilization
nodes.who: Medicaid-enrolled patients receiving care at participating FQHCs — a core FQHC patient population
nodes.what: Enrollment status, plan type, coverage periods, and claims for Medicaid-covered services
nodes.when: Linkage availability mirrors the encounter year with approximately a 2-year processing lag from CMS
nodes.where: CMS data accessed through FSRDC under a separate CMS data use agreement
nodes.why: Reveals how Medicaid coverage gaps and churning disrupt continuity of care at FQHCs
nodes.which: Fee-for-service and managed care Medicaid enrollment files and encounter claims
nodes.how: Medicaid ID or probabilistic match to CMS enrollment records using shared identifiers

nodes.label: Housing Health
nodes.detail: Research enabled: How does housing stability affect FQHC utilization and chronic disease management?
nodes.who: Social determinants researchers studying housing policy impact on health outcomes at FQHCs
nodes.what: Studies linking housing assistance status to FQHC visit frequency and chronic disease management
nodes.when: Analysis possible once HUD linkage approval is granted — typically 3–6 months after application
nodes.where: All analyses within FSRDC secure computing environment; output reviewed before release
nodes.why: Quantifies the health return on investment in housing assistance programs for low-income populations
nodes.which: Cross-sectional and longitudinal housing-health association and program evaluation studies
nodes.how: Regression and propensity score models linking housing assistance status to care utilization

nodes.label: Mortality
nodes.detail: Research enabled: Which ambulatory care patterns predict 5-year mortality risk in FQHC populations?
nodes.who: Epidemiologists and health services researchers studying long-term outcomes after FQHC encounters
nodes.what: Survival analysis and cause-specific mortality studies following ambulatory care encounters
nodes.when: NDI linkage enables mortality follow-up from 2021 FQHC encounters through the most recent NDI year
nodes.where: All analyses within FSRDC secure environment; all output undergoes disclosure review before release
nodes.why: Evaluates care quality through the definitive outcome — whether patients survive following care
nodes.which: All-cause survival, cause-specific mortality, and preventable death rate studies
nodes.how: Kaplan-Meier curves, Cox proportional hazards models, and competing risks analyses

nodes.label: Insurance
nodes.detail: Research enabled: How does Medicaid churning affect continuity of FQHC care and health outcomes?
nodes.who: Health economists and policy analysts studying Medicaid coverage effects on FQHC care continuity
nodes.what: Studies of insurance continuity, churning effects, and downstream healthcare utilization patterns
nodes.when: Enabled once Medicaid linkage is approved; coverage gaps can be traced around each FQHC encounter
nodes.where: FSRDC secure environment; CMS data use agreement required in addition to FSRDC approval
nodes.why: Reveals how coverage gaps disrupt care continuity and worsen health outcomes for FQHC patients
nodes.which: Coverage continuity, churning frequency, and utilization during and after Medicaid coverage gaps
nodes.how: Longitudinal analysis linking enrollment periods to FQHC visit patterns and downstream outcomes

nodes.label: Combined SDH
nodes.detail: Research enabled: How do housing instability and coverage gaps compound to drive the deepest health inequities?
nodes.who: Health equity researchers examining compound social disadvantage and intersecting risk factors
nodes.what: Multi-linkage studies combining housing, mortality, and insurance context around FQHC encounters
nodes.when: Requires simultaneous approval for HUD, NDI, and/or Medicaid linkages — complex multi-step application
nodes.where: Complex multi-file linkage accessed only through FSRDC; additional coordination with NCHS required
nodes.why: Reveals how compounding social disadvantages drive the deepest and most persistent health inequities
nodes.which: Intersectional analyses combining housing, insurance, and mortality for health equity research
nodes.how: Multi-level modeling and mediation analysis across linked social determinants and clinical encounter data

links.description: NAMCS patient identifiers matched to HUD housing assistance records via probabilistic algorithms at NCHS
NAMCS patient identifiers matched to NDI mortality records — match rates exceed 90% for adults with complete SSN
NAMCS patient identifiers linked to CMS Medicaid enrollment files via Medicaid ID or probabilistic match
HUD linkage enables studies of housing assistance impact on FQHC utilization and chronic disease management
NDI linkage enables survival analysis and cause-of-death studies following ambulatory care encounters
Medicaid linkage enables studies of coverage continuity, churning effects, and downstream service use
Combined HUD + NDI + Medicaid linkages reveal how social determinants compound to drive health disparities
Mortality outcomes contextualized by housing and insurance status reveal compound disadvantage in FQHC populations
